stats.notes: Born Prince Rogers Nelson at Mount Sinai Hospital in Minneapolis to parents John L. Nelson and Mattie Shaw. A jazz pianist, John used Prince as a nickname and stage name.
stats.title: Birth

stats.notes: Recorded his first demos with his band Grand Central.
stats.title: First Demos

stats.notes: Warner Bros. Records issued his first album, “For You,” on which he played all the instruments. He was 18 years old, but press releases claimed he was 17.
stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: For You
stats.strib_copy: The first album arrived amid much hype about an 18-year-old who wrote, arranged, played and produced everything himself. The youngest producer in Warner Bros. history went for multi-layered, lush, likable R&B, suggesting a Stevie Wonder wannabe. Crowning cut: The suggestive “Soft and Wet.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: Performed his first shows as Prince with a new band at the Capri Theater in north Minneapolis, a tryout of sorts for Warner Bros. executives.
stats.title: First Shows as Prince

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Prince
stats.strib_copy: Having gone over budget on his debut, Prince showed he could make commercial R&B and funk filled with emotion and falsetto. Crowning cuts: “I Wanna Be Your Lover,” “Why You Wanna Treat Me So Bad,” “I Feel for You.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: Played to a half-full Orpheum Theatre before hitting the road as Rick James’ opening act.
stats.title: First Orpheum Show

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Dirty Mind
stats.strib_copy: A breakthrough in boldness, this album not only explores a wide variety of styles - from new-wave rock to unrelenting dance jams - in a raw, rudimentary sound, but the content is rivetingly Rabelaisian, discussing incest, oral sex and threesomes. Crowning cuts: “Head,” “When You Were Mine,” “Party Up.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: Made his debut at First Avenue nightclub, then called Sam’s, just a few weeks after playing “Saturday Night Live” and a few months after issuing his breakthrough album, “Dirty Mind.” The show sold out fast and would be his last gig there advertised with more than a few days’ notice.
stats.title: First Avenue Debut

stats.notes: The first, and some say the best. The club got him amid the breakthrough raves for his “Dirty Mind” album and right after he made his “Saturday Night Live” debut. Set list included: “Do It All Night,” “Head,” “Partyup,” “Uptown,” “Bambi.”
stats.title: Top Five First Avenue Shows

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Controversy
stats.strib_copy: A somewhat experimental set between two better-realized albums, it pushes the sexual envelope to a sometimes trite point and doesn’t mind getting silly. Crowning cuts: “Do Me Baby,” “Controversy.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.strib_copy: A double-disc exploration of primarily synthesizer funk, this collection is slyly sexy, uncontrollably funky and perfectly playful, with seven of the 11 songs extending beyond six minutes. “1999” has lots of attitude and lots of hits. Crowning cuts: “Little Red Corvette,” “1999,” “Delirious,” “Let’s Pretend We’re Married.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: Played his first local arena show at Met Center after ascending the charts with his “1999” LP.
stats.title: First Met Center Show

stats.notes: Under the guise of a benefit concert for Minnesota Dance Theatre, he debuted a new lineup of the Revolution and new songs in concert at First Avenue, including “Purple Rain” and “I Wound Die 4 U.” Recordings of those songs from that night would be used for the album and film “Purple Rain.”
stats.title: Minnesota Dance Theater Show

stats.notes: The big one. Under the guise of a Minnesota Dance Theatre benefit, he debuted and recorded several of the songs that would wind up in “Purple Rain.” The full recording of that night could be the most wanted album in his vault. Set list included: “Let’s Go Crazy,” “I Would Die 4 U,” “Purple Rain,” Joni Mitchell’s “A Case of You.”
stats.title: Top Five First Avenue Shows

stats.notes: The “Purple Rain” film crew took over Minneapolis, including a three-week shoot at First Avenue that wrapped just before the holidays, plus locations around downtown Minneapolis and in the Longfellow neighborhood.
stats.title: Purple Rain Filming
Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal
Best Album of Original Score Written for a Motion Picture or a Television Special

stats.notes: His surprise birthday party was a fun respite before the “Purple Rain” storm. Set list included: “17 Days,” “Free,” “Erotic City,” “Impossible Bitch.”
stats.title: Top Five First Avenue Shows

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Purple Rain
stats.strib_copy: The album: Playing with a full band for the first time, he expands his musical palette, rocking harder, becoming dreamier and leaving the funk behind. The bass-less minimalism of “When Doves Cry,” his most personal song to date, is as irresistibly entrancing as “Purple Rain” is spiritually transcendent, and “Baby, I’m a Star” is joyous.The movie: Ladies and gentlemen, meet the Kid. He's talented, sexy, cocksure and sure wears a lot of tight pants. Unfortunately, his arrogance as an artist, occasional rudeness to friends and mistrust of the music business threatens to sideline his career. Hmm, 20 years later, can we still call this fiction? Actually, "Purple Rain" stands up as a classic music movie in the realm of "A Hard Day's Night" and "Jailhouse Rock." Sure, the acting is workable at best, and the story is sometimes laughable. But the musical performances are exceptional, and Prince's personality - good and bad - fills the screen. And thanks to the film, Lake Minnetonka still sees more nude cannonballs than any other lake in the state.
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: With “Purple Rain” topping the album charts and breaking box office expectations, he plays to nearly 100,000 hometown fans over a five-night stand at the St. Paul Civic Center, with Christmas Day the only off day.
stats.title: St. Paul Civic Center Shows

stats.notes: Prince and the Revolution Duet with Apollonia
stats.title: Take Me With You

stats.label: Paisley Park, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Around the World in a Day
stats.strib_copy: Prince goes psychedelic with a few odd missteps such as “The Ladder” (co-written with his father) but several mesmerizing, multicolored tracks. Crowning cuts: “Raspberry Beret,” “Pop Life.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.title: Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal

stats.label: Paisley Park, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Parade
stats.strib_copy: Music from the Motion Picture `Under the Cherry Moon’ “: His third album in 20 months is a dizzying pastiche of psychedelic pop, bare-bones funk and Hollywood-flavored soundtrack fare. Crowning cuts: “Kiss,” “Girls and Boys,” “Sometimes It Snows in April.”The movie: A sharp contrast to the brightness of "Purple Rain" in more ways than the black-and-white footage and the scant $7 million gross (compared with $65 million at the time for "Rain"). Prince basically plays a suaver version of himself as he tries to woo a rich heiress, but the charm wears thinner than the story. He also directed the film, which was a fun attempt at making a classic romantic movie but comes off more as an excuse to hang out on the French Riviera and snuggle up to then-newcomer Kristin Scott Thomas. At least the soundtrack had less throwaway material, including "Kiss" and "Sometimes It Snows in April."
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: To the tune of about $10 million, he built Paisley Park Studio near his house in Chanhassen, which would be his primary recording and rehearsal space and the site of countless late-night parties with Prince serving as host and sometimes headliner.
stats.title: Paisley Park Constructed

stats.notes: With Paisley Park under construction, it proved to be his last gig there for 20 years. It also was a warm-up for a tour behind what proved to be another landmark album, “Sign o’ the Times.” Based on bootleg recordings at least, I’d actually say this one’s the best. Set list included: “Housequake,” “Hot Thing,” “Strange Relationship,” “Kiss.”
stats.title: Top Five First Avenue Shows

stats.label: Paisley Park, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Sign o' the Times
stats.strib_copy: The album: Considered superior to “Purple Rain” by many diehards, it’s at least as good for a longer duration (two discs). “Sign” offers the most perfect balance of everything that is Prince: grinding funk, catchy pop, anthemic rock, tender balladry, thoughtful spirituality and urban realism, all spun at a thrilling, loose pace. In many ways, it’s the Lennon to “Purple Rain’s” McCartney. Crowning cuts: “I Could Never Take the Place of Your Man,” “The Cross,” “U Got the Look,” “Housequake.”The movie: While a few dramatic montages are thrown in, this film is essentially just a concert movie. Thank goodness for that. It helps that it is based on one of Prince's best albums, but he could be singing songs from the dreadful "Come" album, and chances are his on-stage charisma would shine on screen. This one might be more essential than "Purple Rain" in telling what the artist is all about.
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.title: I Could Never Take the Place of Your Man

stats.label: Paisley Park, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Lovesexy
stats.strib_copy: Lacking the grandiosity and swiftness of “Sign o’ the Times,” this CD was largely dismissed upon release - in part because of Prince’s nude cover pose - but has proven to be more pivotal. He starts seeking love instead of sex and peace to go with his religion. He also cuts several new sonic paths and infuses hip-hop like never before. Crowning cuts: “Alphabet Street,” “Anna Stesia.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Batman (soundtrack)
stats.strib_copy: This soundtrack is inspired less by Prince’s vision than by the characters in Tim Burton’s dark interpretation of “Batman.” The quickie album includes a little funk, a slice of pop, a sappy Sheena Easton ballad duet, an oversexed pant and a catchy collage of film dialogue and music. Crowning cuts: “Batdance,” “Scandalous.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: Opened his own nightclub, Glam Slam, on 5th Street in Minneapolis’ Warehouse District, which became Quest in the late-1990s after he was no longer involved in it.
stats.title: Glam Slam Opening

stats.notes: He brought another film crew to the Twin Cities to shoot “Graffiti Bridge,” released that November to a tepid response.
stats.title: Graffiti Bridge Filming

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Graffiti Bridge
stats.strib_copy: The album: This 17-song, double-disc is a fully realized, mostly funk-rock exploration of the dichotomy of sensuality and spirituality, performed by the Time, George Clinton, Mavis Staples, Tevin Campbell and Prince. Crowning cuts: The Time’s “Shake,” Staples’ “Melody Cool,” Prince’s “Can’t Stop This Feeling I Got.”The movie: (1991): OK, so maybe movies weren't his thing. Prince's last-gasp effort at reviving his big-screen career fell flat, thanks largely to a lame story about the characters in "Purple Rain" battling over control of Glam Slam nightclub. Prince's penchant for melodrama as an actor didn't help. A half-great soundtrack picked things up, as did the "West Side Story"-like sets and all-star appearances by George Clinton, Mavis Staples and the reunited Time. Alas, the writing really was on the wall.
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Paisley Park, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Diamonds and Pearls
stats.strib_copy: His most blatantly commercial album since “Prince,” it lacks innovation, excitement and emotion. He has switched from leader to follower, adding trendy but forced rap to his repertoire. Crowning cuts: “Diamonds & Pearls,” “Money Don’t Matter 2 Night,” “Cream,” “Gett Off.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Paisley Park, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Love Symbol Album
stats.strib_copy: His most derivative disc, this glyph gaffe comes across like a PG-13, hip-hop-oriented sequel to 1987’s boldly sexual “The Black Album.” Some of the lyrics are ridiculous, but you sure can dance to this disc. Crowning cuts: “My Name Is Prince,” “Sexy MF.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: The Hits 1
stats.strib_copy: This 56-song collection is a testament to his musical range, inventiveness and boldness. But it was assembled by Warner Bros., not Prince, so the choices are safe and predictable - long on pop, short on funk and rarities.
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: The Hits 2
stats.strib_copy: This 56-song collection is a testament to his musical range, inventiveness and boldness. But it was assembled by Warner Bros., not Prince, so the choices are safe and predictable - long on pop, short on funk and rarities.
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: The Hits/The B-Sides
stats.strib_copy: This 56-song collection is a testament to his musical range, inventiveness and boldness. But it was assembled by Warner Bros., not Prince, so the choices are safe and predictable - long on pop, short on funk and rarities.
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.title: The Most Beautiful Girl in the World

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Come
stats.strib_copy: Released to fulfill his contract with Warner Bros., it’s a batch of forgettable songs whose one-word titles (“Orgasm,” “Loose!”) hint at the disinterest involved.
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: The Black Album
stats.strib_copy: Not released until 1994, it was shelved days before it was supposed to be shipped to record stores, which, of course, led to widespread bootlegging and rumors of greatness. They were half-true. Silliness reins, from the uber-sexual “Le Grind” to the Prince-mimicking-himself ballad “When 2 R in Love.” Crowning cuts: “Cindy C.” (an ode to Ms. Crawford), the terrific jam “2 Nigs United 4 West Compton.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG, Warner Bros.
stats.title: The Gold Experience
stats.strib_copy: His most fun and cohesive album since “Sign o’ the Times” is held together by a female narrator with a computerized voice. Crowning cuts: “The Most Beautiful Girl in the World,” “Billy Jack Bitch.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Girl 6
stats.strib_copy: This soundtrack for Spike Lee’s forgettable phone-sex movie compiles some of Prince’s best between-the-sheets romps - including one each by the Family and Vanity 6 - around a couple of new songs. Crowning cuts: “She Spoke 2 Me,” the Family’s “Screams of Passion.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Chaos and Disorder
stats.strib_copy: His swan song on Warner Bros. is a slapped-together throwaway that sounds like mid-’80s Prince. It’s not as bad as the title suggests. But he hits his recorded nadir on “Into the Light” and “I Will.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: After waging war with Warner Bros., he declared his “Emancipation” with a three-disc set announced in a midnight press conference at Paisley.
stats.title: Leaving Warner Bros.

stats.label: NPG, EMI
stats.title: Emancipation
stats.strib_copy: This bedazzling three-hour, three-disc collection is his most adult, mature and jazziest effort. Each CD is themed - old-school pop-soul, a lushly romantic symphony, and street-wise social and spiritual commentary. Prince even does covers of four well-known songs on a package that both summarizes and advances his career. Crowning cuts: “Sex in the Summer,” “I Can’t Make You Love Me,” “Holy River.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.title: New Power Soul
stats.strib_copy: Although credited to the New Power Generation, this 10-track funk fest has Prince all over it. Like most of his jam-filled sessions, however, the funk isn’t as well conveyed on CD as it is live. Crowning cut: “The One.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: Crystal Ball
stats.strib_copy: This four-disc compilation of outtakes and leftovers has its moments of funky fun, but it’s mostly for completists. The all-acoustic “The Truth” is a sonic change of pace. Crowning cut: “Days of Wild.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: The Vault: Old Friends 4 Sale
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG, Arista
stats.title: Rave Un2 the Joy Fantastic
stats.strib_copy: Clive Davis had this crazy idea that an all-star cast could revive a genius’ fading career. It worked for Santana but not so well for Prince, who allows only minimal help from guests Sheryl Crow, Chuck D, Ani DiFranco and Gwen Stefani. At least it sounds as if he had a good time. He also had several strong songs. Crowning cuts: “The Greatest Romance Ever Sold,” “Tangerine.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: NPG Music Club Vol. 1-12
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: Rave In2 the Joy Fantastic
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: The Very Best of Prince
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG, Redline Entertainment
stats.title: The Rainbow Children
stats.strib_copy: Prince’s last “real” album, it is steeped in jazz and soul to great effect. However, its weird voiceovers and indecipherable religious messages make it far too obtuse. If you can get around the head-scratching moments, you’ll probably agree the guy still has it. Crowning cuts: “The Everlasting Now,” “Family Name.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: One Nite Alone...
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG, MP Media
stats.title: One Nite Alone... Live! / One Nite Alone... The Aftershow: It Ain't Over!
stats.strib_copy: This hugely rewarding, three-CD boxed set captures the brilliance, indulgence and frustration of a Prince concert - and the superfunky after-show. This one is all about musicianship and spirit of the highest order. Crowning cut: “Nothing Compare 2 U.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.title: Live at the Aladdin DVD
stats.strib_copy: Taken from the final “One Nite” dates, the concert DVD offers visual proof of the fun Prince had on the tour, with many odd workouts not on the boxed set. Crowning cuts: “Push and Pull” with Nikka Costa and “The Ride.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: Xpectation
stats.strib_copy: No review

stats.label: NPG, MP Media
stats.title: N.E.W.S.
stats.strib_copy: Four 15-minute instrumental jams with the “One Nite” band, it’s Prince’s version of background music. Crowning cut: The John Blackwell rhythm showcase “East.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: The Chocolate Invasion
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: The Slaughterhouse
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: C-Note
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG, Columbia
stats.title: Musicology
stats.strib_copy: This could have a warning sticker: “Suitable for all adults — for a change.” A strikingly mature celebration of marriage and monogamy, this is Prince’s most focused and consistent album since “Lovesexy.” While the music isn’t groundbreaking, the songwriting displays some of his most consistently developed ideas in years. Crowning cuts: “A Million Days,” “Musicology.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG, Universal
stats.strib_copy: Like Prince’s last album with a four-digit title (“1999”), this is a party record, with a throwback vibe that evokes such Prince faves as Carlos Santana, James Brown and Earth, Wind & Fire. While this has some intriguing concepts, one wishes he’d hook up with a younger musical genius like Questlove of the Roots. Crowning cuts: “Black Sweat,” “Satisfied,” “Boat.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: Warner Bros.
stats.title: Ultimate Prince
stats.strib_copy: No review

stats.notes: Booked three shows in one day to celebrate his birthday, starting with a promotional set at Macy’s department store, then a full-fledged Target Center concert (his last local arena show), then an after-hours jam at First Avenue (his last performance at the club). The latter was stopped by police about 45 minutes in because he went on around 2 a.m.
stats.title: Birthday Concerts

stats.notes: The finale to his one-day, three-show 7/7/07 marathon came to an abrupt end after a little more than an hour when police shut it down just before 4 a.m. He did squeeze in an “Alphabet Street” jam with Sheila E., Wendy Melvoin and Larry Graham at the end, though. Set list included: “3121,” “I Feel for You,” “Controversy” and three Sly Stone covers.
stats.title: Top Five First Avenue Shows

stats.label: NPG, Columbia
stats.title: Planet Earth
stats.strib_copy: Musically, this harkens back to the mid-1980s psychedelic and formal pop of "Around the World in a Day" and "Parade." At the same time it signals a renewed commitment to social commentary, with a title track that’s an opulently orchestrated antiwar, pro-green opus. Crowning cuts: "Guitar," "Future Baby Mama."
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: Indigo Nights
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: Lotusflow3r
stats.strib_copy: No review
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: Released as a 3-CD set together with Elixer by Bria Valente
stats.label: NPG
stats.title: Lotusflow3r / MPL Sound
stats.strib_copy: Part of a three-disc Target exclusive (including a solo disc by protege Bria Valente), these albums echo familiar Purple sounds but on current topics, including Wall Street bailouts, the Obama presidency and issues of race. The one-man-band “MPLSound” focuses more on party funk while “Lotusflow3r,” recorded with a band, is more eclectic. Crowning cuts: “Chocolate Box,” “Dance 4 Me,” “$.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: 20Ten
stats.strib_copy: A more appropriate title might be "Nineteen80." Released only in Europe as a giveaway, it exudes the synthesizer minimalism Prince purveyed then, but it was his slightest effort since 1996’s contractual obligation "Chaos and Disorder." Crowning cut: "Lay Down."
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: He played six gigs over three nights at the Dakota Jazz Club in downtown Minneapolis, his most intimate and celebrated hometown shows in decades, some of which included the debut of his new all-woman backing band 3rdEyeGirl.
stats.title: Dakota Jazz Club Shows

stats.notes: He and 3rdEyeGirl played two sets at Myth nightclub in Maplewood, which would be his last hometown performances outside of Paisley Park.
stats.title: Myth Show

stats.label: NPG, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Plectrumelectrum
stats.strib_copy: Recorded with his new backing trio 3rdEyeGirl, there are palpable sparks on this exciting disc, one of two released the same day, and his first for Warner Bros. since 1996. The recording balances heavy-rock workouts with lighter, more crafted pop pieces. Crowning cuts: “Boy Trouble,” “Whitecaps,” “Funknroll.”
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG, Warner Bros.
stats.title: Art Official Age
stats.strib_copy: Seemingly a one-man effort, this half-baked concept album about life, happiness and the afterlife ("artificial age," get it?) sounds a bit like early Prince. Crowning cuts: "Way Back Home," "The Gold Standard."
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: HITnRUN Phase One
stats.strib_copy: Billed as experimental, this EDM-minded collaboration with programmer Joshua Welton is more like a hodgepodge of one-off tracks, leftovers and remixes. Crowning cuts: "1000 X’s & O’s," "June."
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.label: NPG
stats.title: HITnRUN Phase Two
stats.strib_copy: Backed by members of the New Power Generation and a 16-person horn section, Prince combines numbers from recent live sets with a few singles. At least this is funkier than Phase One. Crowning cut: "Baltimore."
stats.author: Jon Bream and Chris Riemenschneider

stats.notes: He offered hometown fans a preview of his Piano & a Microphone Tour, playing two intimate sets to rapturous response. They would be his last time performing at home.
stats.title: Final Hometown Show

stats.notes: Two days after widespread reports he was rushed to a hospital after an emergency landing in Moline, Ill., he hosted a dance party at Paisley Park to reassure fans he’s OK. “Wait a few days before you waste your prayers,” he said in a brief appearance on stage.
stats.title: Final Dance Party

stats.notes: Prince is found dead at his Paisley Park recording studio complex in Chanhassen. He was 57.
stats.title: Death
